item.title: Cars & Climbing: Systems for Quantifying Performance at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
This exhibition was scheduled to open on January 9. Due to the recent storms, it has been pushed back to January 11. We apologize for any inconvenience.

Throughout history, enthusiasts have developed methods to describe and rate performance systematically. Based on archival collections at Stanford, this exhibit explores the genesis of these systems as means for quantifying experiences like the difficulty of a rock climbing route or the quality of the ride that an automobile provides.

This exhibit is free and open to the public during library hours. 

Plan Your Visit

  • Library hours vary throughout the year. The most up-to-date hours of operation are available here.
  • Visit our Access & Privileges page to learn what you will need to bring with you to gain access to the exhibition space.
  • Stanford has a large campus. Be prepared to traverse at least 0.5 miles during your visit.
  • Parking regulations are enforced from 8 AM - 4 PM on weekdays unless otherwise posted.

item.title: From Near to Far: a View of a Cold War-era Aerospace Engineer & His Company at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
This exhibition was scheduled to open on January 9. Due to the recent storms, the opening date has been pushed back to January 13. We apologize for any inconvenience. 

Jack Nielsen was Chief Scientist at NASA Ames, and founder of Vidya Inc., before founding Nielsen Engineering and Research. NEAR today is a division of AMA Inc., but the legacy of Nielsen lives on today in this exhibit. This collection is a rare look inside Cold War aerospace and weapons technology, as well as technical report literature from governments and companies.

This exhibit is free and open to the public during library hours. 

Plan Your Visit

  • Library hours vary throughout the year. Green Library's hours of operation are available here.  
  • Visit our Access & Privileges page to learn what you will need to bring with you to gain access to the exhibition space.
  • Stanford has a large campus. Be prepared to traverse at least 0.5 miles during your visit. 
  • Parking regulations are enforced from 8 AM - 4 PM on weekdays unless otherwise posted.

item.title: Introduction to GDAL/OGR: Working with spatial data at scale.
item.description:
The Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL/OGR) is an open-source translator library for working with geospatial data. GDAL/OGR contains a variety of useful command line utilities that can be easier or more efficient to use than standalone GIS software or rolling your own code. In this workshop you will learn how to use GDAL to:

  • Inspect and query datasets
  • Convert data between different formats
  • Update and transform spatial reference systems (projections)
  • Clip and subset data
  • Create tile indexes and mosaics

This workshop will be held online via Zoom.

item.title: Georeferencing 101 at Green Library
item.description:
Georeferencing in QGIS

This workshop covers the basics of georeferencing static images in a GIS using the open source GIS package QGIS. Georeferenced images or maps can be used as contextual layers in a GIS project, or as part of a data extraction process to convert static map data into digital vector data.

Setting up for best results

Georeferencing from a set of known map coordinates

Georeferencing by linking to a basemap

Digitizing new GIS features from a georeferenced maps

 

Note: Open to current Stanford affiliates ONLY.

item.title: Imagining Maritime Spaces Exhibition at David Rumsey Map Center
item.description: Imagining Maritime Spaces draws together maps of the world’s oceans and seas to explore how cartographers, navigators, and others have historically come to know and to represent these dynamic spaces. Charts, tools, and other visualizations illustrate elements of navigation by stars, winds, and waves, exploration of unknown waters and depths, and shifting coasts. This exhibit coincides with the Computational Archaeology & Seafaring Theory Workshop being sponsored by the Archaeology Center and collaborating centers and institutions both on and beyond campus. The exhibition was curated by Justin Leidwanger, Beth Minney and Nicole Constantine; it was coordinated and mounted by Kristina Larsen.  The exhibition opens at the same time as the Micronesian Seafaring System talk and can be viewed during the Center's open hours until Feb 10, 2023.

item.title: Love Data Fair at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
Celebrate Love Data Week at the Stanford Libraries! 

Love Data Week is an annual festival highlighting topics, opportunities and services relevant to data in research. Love Data Week 2023 will feature a Love Data Fair on the afternoon of Valentine’s Day, February 14th, in Hohbach Hall, Green Library. 

Everyone in the Stanford community is welcome to attend - come to learn, share, and discuss quantitative and qualitative data management, analysis, sharing, privacy, preservation, reuse, delivery, and more!

item.title: Qualitative Data Drop-in workshop: Intro to NVivo with Esha Chatterjee at Hohbach Hall - Green Library
item.description: Stop by Green Library for the Love Data Fair and learn about NVivo from Qualitaitve Data Consultant, Esha Chatterjee. Esha will be available to demo NVivo and show you how to get started with this qualitative data analysis software.  She will be in Green Library - Hohbach Hall from 1:30-2:30PM on Feb 14th.

item.title: Redivis CEO Ian Matthews: Data Resources at the Stanford Data Farm at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
The Stanford Data Farm is a campus platform for accessing, exploring and engaging campus-acquired datasets for your own research needs. Powered by Redivis, the Data Farm allows for fast and highly efficient queries and extracts handled directly in the browser. 

Join Redivis Co-Founder/CEO Ian Matthews (Public Policy & Economics, 2013) for an overview of querying, filtering, descriptive statistics, visualisations, and python notebook functionality.


Datasets on Data Farm are interoperable with common data analysis tools such as: Python, R, SAS, and Stata and can be easily exported to on-premise computing environments such as Farmshare / Sherlock, into cloud compute services like GCP, AWS, Azure, or downloaded for local analysis (usage rights permitting).

This event is part of the Lighting Talk series at the Love Data Week Fair on Tuesday, Feburary 14th. For more information, see this page: https://library.stanford.edu/research-data-services/love-data-week

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Felt: Digital Maps without GIS at Hohbach Hall
item.description: Join Stace Maples, Assistant Director of Geospatial Collections & Services at Stanford, to learn about Felt, a new web-based collaborative mapping tool.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Text Analysis & Machine Learning at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
Interested in learning to work with text data and machine learning? Not sure how to get started? Join Evan Muzzall (Head, Software & Services for Data Science) as he talks about the SSDS Text Analysis & Machine Learning (TAML) Group! 

This community caters to beginners who are looking to get started. Here, you can learn to navigate the text and machine learning landscapes in casual, informal ways that are right for your pace and learning abilities.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Emi Lesure (Census Bureau) on the Federal Statistical Research Data Center at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
Join Emi Lesure, PhD. to learn about Stanford's Federal Statistical Research Data Center.

In partnership with the U.S. Census Bureau, Stanford's Institute for Research in the Social Sciences hosts one of the nation’s 31 Federal Statistical Research Data Centers, providing access to restricted data for researchers from Stanford as well as nearby universities. Approved projects can access microdata from the Census Bureau's economic and demographic surveys and censuses, restricted-use data from NCHS and AHRQ, and administrative data from partnered federal, state, and local governments.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Pianolatron at Hohbach Hall
item.description: Can analog piano rolls be data? Join Stanford Libraries research developers Peter Broadwell and Simon Wiles for a sneak preview of the Pianolatron, an upcoming web-based tool that connects digitized images of historical piano rolls with real-time music synthesis. The Pianolatron brings archival collections to life by integrating thousands of high-resolution scans, computer vision output and metadata records in an interactive app that provides control over playback parameters such as loudness, speed, and other aspects of musical performance.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Mastodon for Scholars at Hohbach Hall
item.description: Decentralized social networks such as Mastodon are emerging as an important site of scholarly discourse.  Join Quinn Dombrowski (Academic Technology Specialist in Literatures, Cultures, and Languages) for an overview of how "Fediverse" systems like Mastodon differ from centralized networks like Twitter.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Globus for Research Data at Hohbach Hall
item.description: Join Karl Kornel, Globus lead for the Stanford Research Computing Center, to learn about using Globus with Stanford systems such as Oak. Globus provides a suite of cloud-based, software-as-a-service services for moving, synchronizing, and sharing big data. SRCC is piloting a Managed Endpoint with the Globus Sharing option enabled.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | Google Earth Engine at Hohbach Hall
item.description: Google Earth Engine is 70 Petabytes of Earth Observation data, in a web browser. Join Stace Maples, Assistant Director of Geospatial Collections & Services at Stanford, to learn about how this research environment can be used for data-centric Sustainability projects.

item.title: ⚡ Talk | ICPSR (Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research) at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
An international consortium of more than 750 academic institutions and research organizations, the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research advances and expands social and behavioral research, acting as a global leader in data stewardship and providing rich data resources and responsive educational opportunities for present and future generations.

Join Ron Nakao, Data and Economics Librarian and Stanford's Official ICPSR Representative, to learn about the ICPSR — and Social Science data services at Stanford more broadly.

item.title: Bonbons, books, and board games at Green Library
item.description:
Looking for the perfect book? Tired of browsing bookshelves to come away empty-handed? We have the perfect solution! Speed dating… but with books.

Valentine's Day with Stanford Libraries

Join us this Valentine’s Day to eat bonbons, play board games, and yes, speed date some books.

  • 7:00 PM | Dessert
  • 7:20 PM | Book Speed Dating
  • 8:00 PM | Board Games

I﻿f you would like to volunteer for this event, we would be happy to have you facilitate a board game. Please use this form to contact us.

If you are not affiliated with Stanford, you are still welcome. You will need to first register at the front desk though, and to check any books, you will need to get a fee-based library card. Read more about visitor access and borrowing.

item.title: Accelerating the Use of Public Geophysical Data for Recharging California's Groundwater
item.description:
Discover the Power of Electromagnetic (EM) Imaging in Improving Groundwater Sustainability in California. Learn about our innovative web-based application, designed to make use of publicly available resistivity data for identifying the ideal locations for managed aquifer recharge. This presentation will highlight the importance of the managed aquifer recharge for enhancing groundwater sustainability and the crucial role of EM imaging for mapping subsurface sediment types. Join us as we delve into our use of open-source tools such as Jupyter and Redivis, and discover how you can transfer these ideas to your own projects to drive research into action.
 
Seogi Kang is a postdoctoral fellow in the the Department of Geophysics at Stanford. His current research focuses on developing an effective workflow to image subsurface hydrostratigraphy at Central Valley of California using airborne electromagnetic method. Seogi is a core contributor to SimPEG, an open source software project for geophysical simulation and inversions.
 
Zoom Link

item.title: Implementing Privacy Reviews in Digital Archival Collections
item.description:
Stanford Libraries’ digital collections contain personally identifiable information and other forms of high-risk data, such as student, medical, and otherwise sensitive records. Archives staff must abide by archival ethics, state law, federal law, and data security requirements set by Stanford University, while making as much material available to the public as possible. Implementing workflows for high-risk data review creates challenges of scale and sustainability. This presentation will outline why and how to review collections for high-risk data, technical approaches, the ongoing evolution of review guidelines.

Annie Schweikert (she/her/hers) is a digital archivist at Stanford Libraries, where she processes, preserves, and makes accessible born-digital archival collections.

Victor Aguilar III is Lab Assistant in Digital Library Systems and Services at Stanford Libraries.

Click here to register for the Zoom link.

item.title: Introduction to GeoPandas
item.description: GeoPandas is an extension of the open-source Python Data Analysis Library, Pandas, which can be used to read, write, and analyze vector geospatial data formats. GeoPandas enables you to easily do operations in Python that would otherwise require a spatial database such as PostGIS. In this workshop, we will introduce GeoPandas and learn how to perform a variety of geospatial data science tasks to work efficiently with geographic vector datasets.

item.title: Preserving Born-Digital Library Materials and Access through Emulation
item.description:
Stanford University Libraries’ Born-Digital Preservation lab will demonstrate the preservation of born-digital source media, offering a virtual walk-through of the disk imaging process and demonstration of how emulation can be used as a potential access strategy.

In this webinar lab staff will describe how we preserve the contents of born digital source media and can use emulation to make these resources available to researchers.
 

Zoom link

item.title: Does Your Data Love You Back? Ensuring Credit for Data Scholarship
item.description:
Datasets are increasingly recognized as valuable contributions to the scholarly record. Join Zach Chandler, Director of Open Scholarship Strategy, and Rochelle Lundy, Director of the Office of Scholarly Communications, to learn how to maximize the impact of your research data.
 

Click here for the Zoom link.
To request a copy of the presentation slides, click here.

This event is part of Love Data Week at Stanford Libraries. Check out other events during the week of February 13th - 17th, including an in-person Fair and Lightning Talks at Green Library on the afternoon of February 14th.

item.title: CIDR Python Data Wrangling
item.description:
This workshop teaches basic data manipulation with Python using the Pandas library, and will cover topics such as loading data into and out of a Pandas DataFrame, performing basic data cleaning, preparation, and analysis, and visualizing relevant aspects of a dataset.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python (or similar knowledge).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Data_Manipulation_with_Python

item.title: ArcGIS StoryMaps 101 with the Esri StoryMaps Editorial Team at The David Rumsey Map Center at Green Library
item.description:
Join members of Esri’s ArcGIS StoryMaps Editorial Team for an introduction to ArcGIS StoryMaps, a digital storytelling tool that enhances your narrative using multimedia and custom maps. Co-hosted by the David Rumsey Map Center (DRMC) and Stanford Geospatial Center (SGC) at Stanford Libraries, this session will include hands-on skill building with a focus on utilizing resources available through Stanford Libraries.

Presented by ArcGIS StoryMaps Editorial Team members:

  • David Asbury
  • Andria Olson
  • Heidi Daulton

We welcome observers but if you would like to participate in the hands-on skill building, please come prepared with the following:

  • Laptop
  • Account access to storymaps.arcgis.com
  • Account with Georeferencer through davidrumsey.com
  • Account with MapTiler through Georeferencer
  • For more information on how to navigate Georeferencer through davidrumsey.com, please refer to the Working with Historical Maps Online: David Rumsey Map Center guide

item.title: Exploring Decentralized Social Media: Mastodon and the Fediverse
item.description:
There has been a recent surge of interest in the social media platform Mastodon. Although it appears similar to Twitter in that it is oriented around composing posts and sharing them with followers, Mastodon is very differently organized: rather than join a single corporate-owned platform, users join one of thousands of decentralized "instances" of the open source Mastodon software, each run by different people and catering to different communities.

This session will offer an informal tour of Mastodon, discuss how to migrate your social media network from Twitter, and highlight factors to consider when deciding what instance to join, including issues of governance, community moderation and standards development. 

Click here to register for this online event.

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays: Decoding the Game of Love at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
Within the context of LoveData Week, this event explores board games that model or simulate the human emotion of love. These games are intended as entertainment but can also function as data simulations modeling complex relationships and complicated social contexts. In this event, we will evaluate the usefulness of such simulations in modeling human emotions in general and we will examine the specific data points chosen as part of both games. What is really being modeled/studied here? What can we learn from the simulations of human behavior that are on display? What data points are not present in these games?

Tabletop Tuesdays is an event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: Intro To Python
item.description: Python has rapidly become the programming language of choice for many people across the world, thanks to its flexibility and ease of use. In this hands-on workshop, attendees will learn some of the basics behind how to program in Python, and how they can leverage the language for different tasks. No prior experience is required.

item.title: CIDR Python Data Visualization
item.description:
Data visualizations are essential to effectively communicate research. This workshop will introduce you to three basic visualizations using the Python matplotlib and seaborn libraries: histogram, boxplot, and scatterplot. 

Register Here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar knowledge)

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/5_Data_visualization_essentials.html

item.title: George Orwell & Peter Stansky: Then and Now at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Join us for a discussion of Professor Peter Stansky's The Socialist Patriot: George Orwell and War (Stanford University Press, 2023), with remarks from John Rodden and Peter Stansky.

By carefully combing through Orwell's published works, Stansky's book teases apart Orwell's often paradoxical views on patriotism and socialism. The Socialist Patriot is ultimately an attempt to reconcile the apparent contradictions between Orwell's commitment to socialist ideals and his sharp critique of totalitarianism by demonstrating the centrality of his wartime experiences, giving twenty-first century readers greater insight into the inner world of one of the most influential writers of the modern age.

Register here to attend the event in person.

Register here to attend the event online.

A reception will follow the presentation. The Socialist Patriot along with other copies of books about Orwell by Stansky and Rodden will be available for purchase and signing. This event is free and open to the public and is co-sponsored by Stanford Libraries and ​the Department of History.

Peter Stansky is the Frances and Charles Field Professor of History Emeritus at Stanford University. His scholarship addresses many of the main themes of modern British history: the dissipation of the Liberal and growth of the Labour parties; the rise of aesthetic modernism (and the central role played by the Bloomsbury Group); the impact of two world wars and the Spanish Civil War on British intellectuals; and postwar manifestations of an "austere," "swinging," and "cool" Britain. He has written extensively on such topics as William Morris, the Bloomsbury Group and George Orwell.

John Rodden is widely regarded as the world’s leading authority on the legacy of George Orwell. Beginning with The Politics of Literary Reputation: The Making and Claiming of ‘St George’ Orwell in 1989, Every Intellectual’s Big Brother in 2006, and continuing with editing The Cambridge Companion to George Orwell in 2007 and The Cambridge Introduction to George Orwell in 2012, The Unexamined Orwell in 2011 and more, he has established himself as the foremost expert on the cultural and political impact of Orwell on the world. His latest book, Becoming George Orwell: Life and Letters, Legend and Legacy, more than justifies that reputation.

item.title: Qualitative Data Workshop: Content Analysis with NVivo
item.description: Join Esha Chatterjee, qualitative data software consultant for Stanford Libraries, for an intermediate level class on content analysis.  Learn how to upload your collection of textual data for content analysis using NVivo software.  Esha will cover coding and other tips.

item.title: Take a break, pet a dog at Science and Engineering Quad, Y2E2 Courtyard
item.description:
The Terman Engineering Library is pleased to have therapy dogs again this quarter. Please join us in the Y2E2 Courtyard on Wednesday, March 1 from 3-4pm. Dog and owner teams from Pet Partners will be providing relaxation and stress relief. In the event of rain, look for us under the covered walkway.

Image Credit: Michael Spencer

item.title: CIDR R Text Analysis
item.description:
Are you interested in analyzing collections of novels or journal articles? Do you want to understand patterns across collections of tweets or other social media data? In this workshop, we'll learn how to import, clean, and analyze collections of text with R using several standard text mining libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • The Introduction to R CIDR workshop or equivalent experience.

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-text-analysis/

item.title: The Photographs of Rod Dresser at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Stanford Libraries presents The Photographs of Rod Dresser, on view March 3, 2023, through May 7, 2023, in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda, Cecil H. Green Library, Bing Wing. 

The exhibition is curated by Roberto Trujillo; produced and designed by Deardra Fuzzell. 

NOTE: Exhibit cases in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda are illuminated from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The exhibition is free and open to the public. Visitors are encouraged to call 650-723-0931 or visit the Library Hours page to confirm hours and access.

item.title: CIDR R Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a beginner-friendly introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts, quantitative data preprocessing for machine learning, and the SuperLearner R package.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/EastBayEv/Intro_ML_R

item.title: CIDR Python Text Analysis
item.description:
This workshop will introduce you to working with text data using the spaCy and textacy Python libraries. You will learn to effectively streamline text preprocessing, understand word tokenization, sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, and named entity recognition using a single document (a short excerpt from H.G. Wells's A Short History of the World) and across a corpus of legal documents. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience)

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Text_Analysis_with_Python

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for March's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: Tracing Sea Routes on Maps: A conversation on the European and Asian contexts with Sara Caputo and Elke Papelitzky
item.description:
Two leading experts will discuss the appearance and function of sea routes on European and East Asian maps, showing the interconnections of the early modern global maritime world.


We have all seen tracks marching across the oceans of a map. Have you ever wondered where they came from and why they are there? In this online event, Sara Caputo (Cambridge) and Elke Papelitzky (KU Leuven) will share their ongoing research on route lines on European and East Asian maps, respectively. They will each give a brief presentation, followed by a conversation moderated by Katherine Parker (BLR Antique Maps).

 

Trailblazers’ wakes: Ship tracks in Western imperial mapping
Sara Caputo, University of Cambridge (UK)

In the ancient and medieval European world, the seas on maps were trackless. The few extant itinerary maps never seem to extend their lines onto the water. In the sixteenth century, however, European mapmakers began to include route lines on their representations of the oceans. These lines were closely linked to the navigational practice of pricking a course on portolan charts. They may have also drawn inspiration from the routes that had long featured in East Asian maritime mapping. However, in a Western context, tracks became a powerful tool to recount individual journeys and establish imperial claims, in relation to developing notions of ‘discovery’. This half of the talk will include some material from Caputo’s forthcoming book, Tracks on the Ocean (under contract with Profile Books).

 

Red lines in the ocean: Sea routes on early modern East Asian maps
Elke Papelitzky, KU Leuven
Many early modern Chinese, Japanese, and Korean maps draw lines in ocean areas that represent sea routes. These lines appear on maps of a single country, of a larger region, or on maps of the globe. They serve a range of different functions from providing information about (imagined) travel to visually integrating East Asia into global networks, reflecting a perception of East Asian mapmakers of their countries being integrated in these networks. Setting East Asian maps in conversations with European ones shows that when map images shift context between Western Europe and East Asia, the function of the route-lines changes. In the case of East Asian maps, these changes further promote the mapmakers’ narrative of early modern East Asia not being isolated but being a part of the global, maritime world.

item.title: CIDR Python Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a gentle introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts. You will learn the basics for classifying text and images using the scikit-learn, lime, and tensorflow Python libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Intro_to_ML_with_Python

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for April's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.
